BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 13,

1911.

TO WORK FOR REMAINING FUNDS

FOUR ALUMNI WERE ELECTED

SMOKER FOR NEW YORK ALUMNI

Homewood Committee Will Meet Soon
and Formulate Plans to Collect
Remaining $800,000.

All to the Maryland House of Delegates.
Newton D. Baker, Jr., A. B.'92,
Mayor of Cleveland.

Association of New York and New Jersey
Holds First Blow-Out at
Chemists' Club.

H. Findlay French, secretary of
the Johns Hopkins Endowment and
Extension Fund Committee, states
that the _committee will meet soon
to formulate plans for securing the
rest of the $2,00D,00D necessary to
remove the University buildings to
Homewood. Approximately $1,200,003 of this amount is already
pledged. He said, "There has been
no meeting of the committee this
fall, but the members will soon convene, to decide how the remaining
$800,0oo will be secured. It is
Practically certain that we shall endeavor to collect this amount outside of the city from philanthropists
and others interested in the welfare
of the University. We shall not
appeal to Baltimoreans as a whole,
but if there are any citizens who
would like to help in the extension
`A.Trk, we shall welcome their subscriptions. As for the actual building at Homewood, no work will be
done this winter. Corps of men
have been grading the tract,of -land
this summer and some foundations
have been marked off. This work
will be resumed in the spring. The
Building Committee has been enlarged in order to make the work
more systematic, and they have already made some definite plans but
do not wish to announce just what
these plans are until later.
"To work on the committees necessitates a great sacrifice of personal business. During the local
campaign last winter the members
of the committee left their business
for days at a time and it meant a
great loss to them. This is probably the reason why they have not
Yet gotten to work. However, we
shall soon meet and set out to complete the fund."
Some persons interested in the
On to Homewood" movement are
Of the opinion that
the State of
Maryland should complete the fund.
They point out the fact that in
1910, the Commonwealth of Wisconsin gave $1,196,500 for extension work and improvements at the
state university at Madison; and
also that Michigan and Nebraska
annually give $640,000 and $565.000, respectively, to their state universities. It is true that Johns Hopkins is not a state university, but
there are persons who still think
the State of Maryland should complete the fund.
B. Howell Griswold, chairman of
the committee,
stated last Friday
l'at no substantial increases had
)een made in the
fund.

Of the seven alumni on the State
and city tickets, in the recent election, Hopkins men will be glad to
see that four were elected. At first
sight this may seem a very small
number, but one must remember
how very few college or professional men run for the State Legislature. Indeed, this has been one
of the crying needs of the State
for many years. Probably several
years ago we would have been .fortunate to have one or two of our
alumni among the law Makers,
whereas, now we have four. The
successful alumni were as follows:
William H. Maltbie, Ph. D. '95,
one of the Republican Representatives to the House of Delegates
from the Second Legislative District.
Edmund B. Lowndes, A. B. 'cm,
one of the Democratic Representatives to the House of Delegates
from Howard county.
_
Ogle Mar-bury, A. B. '02, one of
the Democratic Representatives to
the House of Delegates from Prince
George's county. (A probable candidate for the speakership.)
Thomas G. Campbell, A. B. 'o6,
one of the Democratic Representatives to the House of Delegates
from Baltimore county.
Not only are our alumni taking
an active part in politics in Maryland, but also from another State
reports come in of the election of a
Hopkins alumnus to a high office.
This alumnus is Newton Diehl
Baker, Jr., who came here in 1889
from Martinsburg, W. Va. He received the degree of Bachelor of
Arts in 1892, and, after a year's
pest-graduate work here, went to
Washing-ton and Lee, where, in
1894, he got the LL. B. degree.
The next two years were spent as
private secretary to PostmasterGeneral Wilson. Then after practicing law for several years at Martinsburg, he moved to Cleveland,
0., where he resumed the practice
of law.
He was a professor in. the Baldwin University of Ohio, and City
Solicitor of Cleveland. Here he
became one of the lieutenants of
the late Tom L. Johnson. On Tuesday last Ile was elected mayor of
Cleveland, and had the honor of receiving the largest plurality(17,000)
a candidate has ever received. Mr.
Baker declared the result was "a
monument to the late Tom L. Johnson."

The Association of Johns Hopkins Alumni of New York and New
ersey held their first smoker Wednesday night at the Chemists' Club
in New York City. There were a
number of ex-Hopkins men present,
and Charles A. Boston, president
of the Association, spoke on Johns
Hopkins men and what they are
doing.
"We all know," he said, "of the
work of Dr. Simon Flexner in investigating what we commonl
know as infantile paralysis; of Dr.
Abraham Flexner, his brother, who
attracted attention because of his
report on the defects of professional
schools to the Carnegie Institution,
and of Dr. Canby Robinson and
his plans for the Rockefeller Hospital. Mr. John Glenn is high in
authority in the Sage Foundation;
and then there are Governor Wilson, of New Jersey; Professor Hadley, of Yale; and President Finley,
di the •College of the -C-ity -New,
York. Then, too, there is Dr. J.
M. T. Finney, who is reported to
be chosen president of Princeton,
though, if he has been, I want to
commiserate with Baltimore on his
loss to Hopkins, and Dr. Walter
Page, editor of World's Work; Dr.
Albert Shaw and Dr. Fabian Franklin, of the Post, are all Hopkins
men."
President Boston was warmly applauded when he sat down. There
were more addresses by Mr. Glenn,
Professor Hyslop, and others, and
the first smoker of the season was
voted an immense success.
The officers of the Association
are:
President—Charles A. Boston, 24
Broad street, New York City.
Vice-President—Thomas W.Hastings, M. D., 172 E. 71st street,
New York City.
Secretary—Robert S. Lanier, 13
Astor Place, New York City.
Treasurer—Arthur Wright, 220
Broadway, New York City.
It is estimated that there are four
lmndred and ninety alumni in New
York 'and New Jersey. Of these,
ninety-six have become members of
the Association.
It is expected that at the next
smoker early in January there will
be a musical program furnished by
members of the Association. The
annual dinner is to be held on the
first Wednesday in March, 1912,
and Dr. Remsen has consented to
be present and speak.

VIRGINIA, 34 HOPKINS, 0
Varsity Goes Bravely Down Before the
Most Formidable Opponents Hopkins
Has Ever Met on the Gridiron.

Before more than five thousand
spectators, and a determined assembly of disappointed but loyal
rooters, the Hopkins football team
went down to defeat last Saturday
at the hands of Virginia by a score
of 34 to o. The size of the score
indicates nothing of the fierceness
of the contest. The Hopkins team
made a splendid fight, and the
struggle, from start to finish, was
full of vim.
The game started off quick and
snappy. Gillet kicked off. After considerable punting, in which 'Virginia
had a decided advantage, the winners punted to Hopkins'5-yard line,
and after a fierce struggle, managed
to push the ball over for the first
touchdown. Yeager kicked goal.
The punting continued and the first
quarter ended with no further
change in score.
Virginia began the second quarter
with a rush. Through the failure
oi a forward pass, Hopkins secured
the ball on its 5-yard line, and Fulton punted to the 40-yard line.
Here Todd, of Virginia, caught it
and broke through the Hopkins.
line for a second touchdown. Yeager
kicked goal.
At the beginning of the third
quarter, Yeager, of Virginia, caught
one of Gillet's forward passes and
ran 40 yards to make a touchdown.
He kicked goal. Another punting
duel ensued in the course of which
Virginia made a touchback. Hopkins attempted several poorly executed forward passes, and the
Virginians made their fourth touchdown. No goal was kicked. At
this point Hopkins woke up for
an instant. Gillet made 10 yards,
Pieper, To; Branham, io; Pieper,
10 more, and Dodson, 10
Hopkins braced up again at the
beginning of the last quarter, but
soon lost the ball on an attempted
forward pass, and Virginia rushed
it"down the field for a touchdown.
Davidson missed the goal. The
last touchdown, also, Virginia carried by storm. Gillet had kicked
off to Virginia's I-yard line. In
two plays, Virginia brought the ball
to Hopkins' 35-yard line, and in the
next play put it over. Goal was
kicked. The rest of the game was
a listless sparring against time.
No part of the defeat can be
charged to the Hopkins rooters.
Under the able leadership of Freddie
Lee, they did their duty well, yelling when the team was gaining and

shall be of a literary character, is of
doubtful wisdom.
Here at Hopkins we had the
honor of having the first arbitration society at any university in
the Southeast, and the work which,
in a humble way, was done in behalf of the peace movement was
very creditable. The First Marylatid
Oratorical Contest was held under
the society's auspices and its members stood well in the Lake Mohonk
Prize Essay Competition.
For the undergraduate body,
there are already quite enough student societies. One which has literary aims may exist and we hope
that it will. It can do no harm. What
we regret is that the arbitration element of the society has been lost, for
college sentiment in support of the
peace movement is rapidly gaining
headway, and more student societies
are being formed every year.. It
would have been better to keep the
Arbitration Society unchanged, so
far as the constitution is concerned,
and if there was sufficient demand,
to introduce literary features.

will issue a card later upon satisfactory evidence of the student's illness. The exceptions to the rule
of free treatment are described on
the blanks soon to be issued.

movement is on fo;)t looking
toward the establishment of a literary and debating society. At the
first annual meeting of the Arbitration Society it was unanimously resolved to make that organization the
nucleus of such a society ; and a committee, .consisting of P. 0. Carter,
chairman ; G. Y. Rusk, A. Wolman,
Harry Corner, and Claude Uhler,
was appointed to draw up a new
constitution, it is proposed that
the society shall devote two or more
meetings every year to the discussion of problems .connected with
arbitration, and that it shall continue to hold the Maryland Intercollegiate Peace Contests in Oratory under its auspices ; but that at
other times its functions shall be
those of a literary and debating soCiety. According to present plans,
the- society will hold weekly contests in declamation, public speaking and debate. At the end of the
year a final contest will be held, to
the winners of which medals will
be given. It has also been suggested that the society enter upon
the field left vacant by the defunct
Haresfoot Club, and present a play
during the season. Interest appears
to have been generally aroused.
The need for such an organization at Hopkins calls for no cominent. Aside from the fact that the
society would afford an opportunity,
for a kind of entertainment that we
have never before been able to know
to any great extent, it would also
accomplish a really useful purpose.
It would give the men who are unable to make the regular debating
teams a chance to get practice in
Public speaking-. Many a man it
might fit to make those teams. It
Would, in short, afford opportunity
not so Much for the display of unusual oratorical ability as for the
steady improvement of the average
Speaker ; and it. nitist not be forgotten, it can afford a good deal of
fun, too.
The society proposes to get to
'work at as early a date as possible.

ship, consisting of j. H. Uhler, 'f3 ;

all who desire to join the society,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 13,

1911.

TO WORK FOR REMAINING FUNDS

FOUR ALUMNI WERE ELECTED

SMOKER FOR NEW YORK ALUMNI

Homewood Committee Will Meet Soon
and Formulate Plans to Collect
Remaining $800,000.

All to the Maryland House of Delegates.
Newton D. Baker, Jr., A. B.'92,
Mayor of Cleveland.

Association of New York and New Jersey
Holds First Blow-Out at
Chemists' Club.

H. Findlay French, secretary of
the Johns Hopkins Endowment and
Extension Fund Committee, states
that the _committee will meet soon
to formulate plans for securing the
rest of the $2,00D,00D necessary to
remove the University buildings to
Homewood. Approximately $1,200,003 of this amount is already
pledged. He said, "There has been
no meeting of the committee this
fall, but the members will soon convene, to decide how the remaining
$800,0oo will be secured. It is
Practically certain that we shall endeavor to collect this amount outside of the city from philanthropists
and others interested in the welfare
of the University. We shall not
appeal to Baltimoreans as a whole,
but if there are any citizens who
would like to help in the extension
`A.Trk, we shall welcome their subscriptions. As for the actual building at Homewood, no work will be
done this winter. Corps of men
have been grading the tract,of -land
this summer and some foundations
have been marked off. This work
will be resumed in the spring. The
Building Committee has been enlarged in order to make the work
more systematic, and they have already made some definite plans but
do not wish to announce just what
these plans are until later.
"To work on the committees necessitates a great sacrifice of personal business. During the local
campaign last winter the members
of the committee left their business
for days at a time and it meant a
great loss to them. This is probably the reason why they have not
Yet gotten to work. However, we
shall soon meet and set out to complete the fund."
Some persons interested in the
On to Homewood" movement are
Of the opinion that
the State of
Maryland should complete the fund.
They point out the fact that in
1910, the Commonwealth of Wisconsin gave $1,196,500 for extension work and improvements at the
state university at Madison; and
also that Michigan and Nebraska
annually give $640,000 and $565.000, respectively, to their state universities. It is true that Johns Hopkins is not a state university, but
there are persons who still think
the State of Maryland should complete the fund.
B. Howell Griswold, chairman of
the committee,
stated last Friday
l'at no substantial increases had
)een made in the
fund.

Of the seven alumni on the State
and city tickets, in the recent election, Hopkins men will be glad to
see that four were elected. At first
sight this may seem a very small
number, but one must remember
how very few college or professional men run for the State Legislature. Indeed, this has been one
of the crying needs of the State
for many years. Probably several
years ago we would have been .fortunate to have one or two of our
alumni among the law Makers,
whereas, now we have four. The
successful alumni were as follows:
William H. Maltbie, Ph. D. '95,
one of the Republican Representatives to the House of Delegates
from the Second Legislative District.
Edmund B. Lowndes, A. B. 'cm,
one of the Democratic Representatives to the House of Delegates
from Howard county.
_
Ogle Mar-bury, A. B. '02, one of
the Democratic Representatives to
the House of Delegates from Prince
George's county. (A probable candidate for the speakership.)
Thomas G. Campbell, A. B. 'o6,
one of the Democratic Representatives to the House of Delegates
from Baltimore county.
Not only are our alumni taking
an active part in politics in Maryland, but also from another State
reports come in of the election of a
Hopkins alumnus to a high office.
This alumnus is Newton Diehl
Baker, Jr., who came here in 1889
from Martinsburg, W. Va. He received the degree of Bachelor of
Arts in 1892, and, after a year's
pest-graduate work here, went to
Washing-ton and Lee, where, in
1894, he got the LL. B. degree.
The next two years were spent as
private secretary to PostmasterGeneral Wilson. Then after practicing law for several years at Martinsburg, he moved to Cleveland,
0., where he resumed the practice
of law.
He was a professor in. the Baldwin University of Ohio, and City
Solicitor of Cleveland. Here he
became one of the lieutenants of
the late Tom L. Johnson. On Tuesday last Ile was elected mayor of
Cleveland, and had the honor of receiving the largest plurality(17,000)
a candidate has ever received. Mr.
Baker declared the result was "a
monument to the late Tom L. Johnson."

The Association of Johns Hopkins Alumni of New York and New
ersey held their first smoker Wednesday night at the Chemists' Club
in New York City. There were a
number of ex-Hopkins men present,
and Charles A. Boston, president
of the Association, spoke on Johns
Hopkins men and what they are
doing.
"We all know," he said, "of the
work of Dr. Simon Flexner in investigating what we commonl
know as infantile paralysis; of Dr.
Abraham Flexner, his brother, who
attracted attention because of his
report on the defects of professional
schools to the Carnegie Institution,
and of Dr. Canby Robinson and
his plans for the Rockefeller Hospital. Mr. John Glenn is high in
authority in the Sage Foundation;
and then there are Governor Wilson, of New Jersey; Professor Hadley, of Yale; and President Finley,
di the •College of the -C-ity -New,
York. Then, too, there is Dr. J.
M. T. Finney, who is reported to
be chosen president of Princeton,
though, if he has been, I want to
commiserate with Baltimore on his
loss to Hopkins, and Dr. Walter
Page, editor of World's Work; Dr.
Albert Shaw and Dr. Fabian Franklin, of the Post, are all Hopkins
men."
President Boston was warmly applauded when he sat down. There
were more addresses by Mr. Glenn,
Professor Hyslop, and others, and
the first smoker of the season was
voted an immense success.
The officers of the Association
are:
President—Charles A. Boston, 24
Broad street, New York City.
Vice-President—Thomas W.Hastings, M. D., 172 E. 71st street,
New York City.
Secretary—Robert S. Lanier, 13
Astor Place, New York City.
Treasurer—Arthur Wright, 220
Broadway, New York City.
It is estimated that there are four
lmndred and ninety alumni in New
York 'and New Jersey. Of these,
ninety-six have become members of
the Association.
It is expected that at the next
smoker early in January there will
be a musical program furnished by
members of the Association. The
annual dinner is to be held on the
first Wednesday in March, 1912,
and Dr. Remsen has consented to
be present and speak.

VIRGINIA, 34 HOPKINS, 0
Varsity Goes Bravely Down Before the
Most Formidable Opponents Hopkins
Has Ever Met on the Gridiron.

Before more than five thousand
spectators, and a determined assembly of disappointed but loyal
rooters, the Hopkins football team
went down to defeat last Saturday
at the hands of Virginia by a score
of 34 to o. The size of the score
indicates nothing of the fierceness
of the contest. The Hopkins team
made a splendid fight, and the
struggle, from start to finish, was
full of vim.
The game started off quick and
snappy. Gillet kicked off. After considerable punting, in which 'Virginia
had a decided advantage, the winners punted to Hopkins'5-yard line,
and after a fierce struggle, managed
to push the ball over for the first
touchdown. Yeager kicked goal.
The punting continued and the first
quarter ended with no further
change in score.
Virginia began the second quarter
with a rush. Through the failure
oi a forward pass, Hopkins secured
the ball on its 5-yard line, and Fulton punted to the 40-yard line.
Here Todd, of Virginia, caught it
and broke through the Hopkins.
line for a second touchdown. Yeager
kicked goal.
At the beginning of the third
quarter, Yeager, of Virginia, caught
one of Gillet's forward passes and
ran 40 yards to make a touchdown.
He kicked goal. Another punting
duel ensued in the course of which
Virginia made a touchback. Hopkins attempted several poorly executed forward passes, and the
Virginians made their fourth touchdown. No goal was kicked. At
this point Hopkins woke up for
an instant. Gillet made 10 yards,
Pieper, To; Branham, io; Pieper,
10 more, and Dodson, 10
Hopkins braced up again at the
beginning of the last quarter, but
soon lost the ball on an attempted
forward pass, and Virginia rushed
it"down the field for a touchdown.
Davidson missed the goal. The
last touchdown, also, Virginia carried by storm. Gillet had kicked
off to Virginia's I-yard line. In
two plays, Virginia brought the ball
to Hopkins' 35-yard line, and in the
next play put it over. Goal was
kicked. The rest of the game was
a listless sparring against time.
No part of the defeat can be
charged to the Hopkins rooters.
Under the able leadership of Freddie
Lee, they did their duty well, yelling when the team was gaining and

Here at Hopkins we had the
honor of having the first arbitration society at any university in
the Southeast, and the work which,
in a humble way, was done in behalf of the peace movement was
very creditable. The First Marylatid
Oratorical Contest was held under
the society's auspices and its members stood well in the Lake Mohonk
Prize Essay Competition.
For the undergraduate body,
there are already quite enough student societies. One which has literary aims may exist and we hope
that it will. It can do no harm. What
we regret is that the arbitration element of the society has been lost, for
college sentiment in support of the
peace movement is rapidly gaining
headway, and more student societies
are being formed every year.. It
would have been better to keep the
Arbitration Society unchanged, so
far as the constitution is concerned,
and if there was sufficient demand,
to introduce literary features.

movement is on fo;)t looking
toward the establishment of a literary and debating society. At the
first annual meeting of the Arbitration Society it was unanimously resolved to make that organization the
nucleus of such a society ; and a committee, .consisting of P. 0. Carter,
chairman ; G. Y. Rusk, A. Wolman,
Harry Corner, and Claude Uhler,
was appointed to draw up a new
constitution, it is proposed that
the society shall devote two or more
meetings every year to the discussion of problems .connected with
arbitration, and that it shall continue to hold the Maryland Intercollegiate Peace Contests in Oratory under its auspices ; but that at
other times its functions shall be
those of a literary and debating soCiety. According to present plans,
the- society will hold weekly contests in declamation, public speaking and debate. At the end of the
year a final contest will be held, to
the winners of which medals will
be given. It has also been suggested that the society enter upon
the field left vacant by the defunct
Haresfoot Club, and present a play
during the season. Interest appears
to have been generally aroused.
The need for such an organization at Hopkins calls for no cominent. Aside from the fact that the
society would afford an opportunity,
for a kind of entertainment that we
have never before been able to know
to any great extent, it would also
accomplish a really useful purpose.
It would give the men who are unable to make the regular debating
teams a chance to get practice in
Public speaking-. Many a man it
might fit to make those teams. It
Would, in short, afford opportunity
not so Much for the display of unusual oratorical ability as for the
steady improvement of the average
Speaker ; and it. nitist not be forgotten, it can afford a good deal of
fun, too.
The society proposes to get to
'work at as early a date as possible.
eetings will be held in the DonoYn Room on Thursdays at one
o clock. A committee on memb
ship, consisting of j. H. Uhler, 'f3 ;

all who desire to join the society,

"Mister," inquired Dusty Rhodes,
"would you contribute 'a dollar to
help beautify your thriving city ?"
"What's the idea?"
"A dollar will buy me a ticket to
the next town."
"I don't understand," wrote the
college boy home, "why you call
yourself a kind parent. I haven't
had a check from you for five weeks.
May I ask what sort of kindness that
is called?"
His father wrote back:"TJnremittin.- kindness."

St. John's Next Saturday.

The annual game with St. John's
will be played as usual on Homewood Field next Saturday. The
game will be of special interest
this season, because St. John's
looks much better than Hopkins on
The only comparative
paper.
'scores are these:
St. John's, 0; Navy, 21.
Hopkins, 6; Navy, 27.
St. John's, 27; Md. "Aggies," o.
• Hopkins, 6; Md. "Aggies," 3.
The Navy scores throw no light
upon the strength of the two teams
at the present time, though Hopkins had the better score; but the'
scores of each team against the
Agricultural College
laryland
might cause a timorous person
much fear for Hopkins. Since
the M. A. C. game, however,
Hopkins has braced up and won
the Gallaudet game two weeks
ago. Since then there has been
much more improvement and more
new men have reported in preparation for the Virginia game. The
result of this struggle will determine, as much as such scores ever
do, the strength of St. John's and
of Hopkins, for Virginia beat St.
John's, 6-o. Therefore, the conditions prevailing make the approaching game with the Cadets
of much interest.
Hopkins students will parade to
Homewood from the University
with a military band at their head.
The undergraduate classes will
follow in separate columns, and
large bodies of alumni will fill out
the ranks.
A part of the grandstand will be
reserved for the men who come out
in the parade and who will form
the cheering section.
